p: 9. The result: the being of man has been overlooked. Both Christianity and Greek philosophy treat the human being as a thing and overlook the human mode of being—or else just treat humans as objectively present creatures. The Christian and Greek views get intertwined in modern philosophy, where the starting point becomes the res cogitans, the mind as a “thinking thing” and the interconnectedness of its experiences. But the being of the cogitationes is either left undefinted or assumed to be obvious and in no need of philosophical inquiry. Hence the foundations of the various theories of human being remain unstable.
